children.subject: does this imply Fall is assumed to be in person (i.e. not completely online)?
My understanding is that we don't know yet. My question, and the posted google spreadsheet, only applies for the case when fall is in-person.

LA times published an article quoting a UCLA professor saying fall is probably in person. Check https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america for projections. Seems like the last death will be long before school starts.

>Seems like the last death will be long before school starts.

The graphs title and axis is predicting deaths per day. The rate goes to 0 means that they expect the daily death rate to be less than 1, rather than indicating when the last death will happen.
Yes, but as we can see, from mid June to August, there are no deaths.
*late June

There are countless models and simulations tracking the pandemic right now. Please at least read the full FAQ for info on what assumptions the IHME model make, what it does and does not claim to predict. For example, disclaimers may includes:

"does not predict how many deaths there may be if social distancing is not fully implemented and maintained through the end of May, or if there is a resurgence after early August."

"It is important to note that the data on daily deaths may fluctuate dramatically due to inconsistencies in reporting."

"we assume that governments will put social distancing measures in place to reduce deaths from COVID-19"

Also, I'd be extremely skeptical of any predictions that claims zero deaths with absolutely no sort confidence intervals what so ever. A wonderful way to maximize your cost function.

Yeah, I'll trust that model when I see results that confirm it.  I think the university is operating under that same paradigm, which is why we probably won't find out if fall classes will be in person for a while.
https://medium.com/@wpegden/a-call-to-honesty-in-pandemic-modeling-5c156686a64b

First, this article's claim that longer periods of isolation "results in 50% more infections and deaths" is contingent on the model's assumption that SARS-CoV-2 spreads better in the winter than in the summer.  While this is true of many other known coronaviruses, it's not conclusive whether or not this is true of this coronavirus.  For example, this study (http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~msantill/Mauricio_Santillana/Publications_files/Luo_et_al_2020_Absolute_Humidity_R0_COVID-19.pdf) concludes that "changes in weather alone (i.e., increase of temperature and humidity as spring and summer months arrive in the North Hemisphere) will not necessarily lead to declines in case counts without the implementation of extensive public health interventions".  Secondly, this article's model doesn't account for the fact that as infections skyrocket, the capacity of the healthcare system decreases.  Not only are patients who are denied access to hospitals due to overcrowding more likely to die than those who receive medical treatment, prolonged periods of overcrowding make medical workers overworked and more likely to get sick, reducing their capacity to treat patients.  Third, I believe that the best way to minimize the amount of deaths when everything reopens is to buy time by continuing to practice physical distancing and stay-at-home orders now.  For everything to run as close to normal as possible, we need many important things to happen, including accessible mass antigen and antibody testing, so those who have been infected and recovered know they won't get infected again, and so that people who do get COVID-19 can self-isolate, reducing the spread of the virus.  We also need to manufacture more masks and other forms of PPE for doctors, nurses, and other medical workers, so that the people saving our lives are able to keep doing their job.  Finally, we will hopefully develop a COVID-19 vaccine (note: it can take multiple years to develop a vaccine that is both safe and effective, I don't think we should stay locked down for years because that would be ridiculous, but every day of time bought counts).

Actually I don't agree with most of the claims pushed in that article either, but I was linking it more to emphasize people's over-reliance on models. In any case most of the benefits you mentioned are indeed the real benefits that come from "flattening the curve." But this all has to do more with the pandemic at large rather than what University policy should be re: class delivery format in FA20. Of which I am firmly of the opinion that virtual only for large classes is the way to go.
Pretty much people go virtual only for big CS classes anyway. Lectures in 61C have like 30 people
Is it possible to have large classes, over 50 people, be webcast-ed to facilitate social distancing?

In the past, they haven't due to the large course size. I've already enrolled and waitlisted to both classes for now without any problem (I'm a non major as of now). It just shows a warning that you have overlapping final times. It depends on the instructors if they will allow conflicts. Now that Fall 2020 has likelihood of being optionally online or being cancelled, your judgement to enroll in both has probably changed.
There's no alternate final for 170 most probably
Does CS 188 allow time conflicts? I'm planning on taking it with CS 170, and they have lecture at the same time.
If we can choose online mode for Fall 2020, does  that mean all classes are webcasted?
I’m enrolled in 126 and 127. Any info if these classes offer alternate finals?
If you have a class conflict with CS 61B, will alternate CS 61B finals be available? Thank you!
Will CS 162 be webcast for students who will be in different time zones for the Fall semester?

history.content:
Dear all,

Here is the best current information about which EECS courses for Fall 2020 will be webcast. I will leave it up here, so you can track changes if they occur.

Sincerely,

Heather
